Mon Jun 29 14:06:06 CEST 2020: Invalid Data, Trying again...
Mon Jun 29 14:06:06 CEST 2020: <td> <h2>5.1 Introduction</h2> <p>In this chapter emission estimates for radiatively important gases generated in 40 Special Report on Emission Scenarios (SRES) scenarios are present. These gases are carbon dioxide (CO<sub><small>2</small></sub>), methane (CH<small><sub>4</sub></small> ), nitrous oxide (N<small><sub>2</sub></small>O), nitrogen oxides (NO<sup>x</sup>), carbon monoxide (CO), non-methane volatile organic compounds (NMVOCs), sulfur dioxide (SO<small><sub>2</sub></small> ), chlorofluoro-carbons (CFCs) and hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFCs)<a href="index.php?idp=fn6#1" onclick="showFootnote(6,1); return false;"><sup>1</sup></a>, hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), and sulfur hexafluoride (SF<small><sub>6</sub></small> ) (see <a href="#tbl51">Table 5-1</a>). Emission estimates presented here span the interval from 1990 to 2100 at the global level and at the level of four SRES macro-regions (OECD90, REF, ASIA, and ALM; see <a href="index.php?idp=150">Appendix IV</a>). In addition, sulfur emission estimates are presented in the regional gridded format to assist in quantifying the effects at the local level. Links between emissions and the underlying driving forces presented in <a href="index.php?idp=89">Chapter 4</a> are illustrated also.</p> <b><br> <a name="tbl51"></a></b> 
 <table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="2" align="center"> 
  <tbody>

 </table> <p><br> As a result of differences in modeling and estimation approaches, base-year (1990) emission values in SRES scenarios developed using different models show substantial variation. To facilitate both use of the scenarios and comparisons across scenarios and families, base-year emissions in all 40 SRES scenarios were standardized using one common set of values (see <a href="index.php?idp=115#box51">Box 5-1</a>). With a few clearly indicated exceptions, only standardized emission values are discussed in this chapter. A complete set of standardized emissions, along with other quantitative scenario information, is provided in <a href="index.php?idp=164">Appendix VII</a>.</p> <b><br> <a name="box51"></a></b> 
 <table border="1" cellpadding="4" align="center"> 
  <tbody>
   <tr> 
    <td> <p><b>Box 5-1: Scenario Standardization</b></p> <p>One of the primary reasons for developing emissions scenarios is to enable coordinated studies of climate change, climate impacts, and mitigation options and strategies. With the multi-model approach used in the SRES process, 1990 and 2000 emissions do not agree in scenarios developed using different models. In addition, even with agreed reference values, it is time consuming and often impractical to fine-tune most integrated assessment models to reproduce a particular desired result. </p> <p>Nevertheless, differences in the base year and 2000 emissions may lead to confusion among the scenario users. Therefore, the 1990 and 2000 emission estimates were standardized in all the SRES scenarios, with emissions diverging after the year 2000. The procedure for selecting 1990 and 2000 emission values and the subsequent adjustments to scenario emissions are described in this box.</p> <p> The standardized scenarios share the same values for emissions in both 1990 and 2000. Emissions for the year 2000 are, of course, not yet known and 1990 emissions are also uncertain. The 1990 and 2000 emission estimates for all gases, except SO<small><sub>2</sub></small> , were set to be equal to the averages of initial values in the unadjusted four marker scenarios. This was carried out at the four-region level, and summed to obtain the standardized global totals. The resultant estimates are within relevant uncertainty ranges for each substance, but should not be interpreted as "endorsed" by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) to represent values for either global or regional emissions. Rather, they are the standardized base-year estimates used for the emissions scenarios. </p> <p>From 2000 to 2100, emissions in all the scenarios (except CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions from land-use and SO<small><sub>2</sub></small> emissions) were adjusted by applying a constant offset equal to the difference between the standardized 2000 value and the scenario-specific 2000 value. The purpose was to smooth scenario trajectories between 2000 and 2010. </p> <p>This procedure results in small distortions for those emissions that rise with time, or at least that do not ultimately decrease by a large amount as compared to the base year. However, for emissions that fall significantly over time, such as those from deforestation or of SO<small><sub>2</sub></small> , this procedure can cause more significant distortions and can even change the sign of the emission estimates at later times (i.e., change positive emission estimates into negative ones and vice versa). To avoid these distortions, for the aforementioned emissions, the year 2000 offset was reduced by 10% per decade, cumulatively, to make the offset zero by the year 2100. This allows preservation of the shape of emission trajectories and still ensures the 2000 standardization. </p> <p>The non-standardized scenario values are available from the modeling teams upon request, although the standardized values should be used for most purposes.</p> </td> 
   </tr> 
  </tbody>
 </table> <p><br> The first section in this chapter presents a "roadmap" that serves as an orientation to the 40 SRES scenarios. The roadmap gives a simple taxonomy that compares input parameters, as represented by the four scenario families, and emission outputs, as represented by the 1990 to 2100 cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions. The subsequent sections discuss in detail emissions of each gas over the next 100 years to 2100.</p> <h2>5.2. Roadmap to the Scenarios<a name="52"></a></h2> <p>A classification scheme is presented here to assist the reader in understanding the links between driving forces and scenario outputs. This scheme can also be used to help select appropriate scenarios for further analysis (see <a href="index.php?idp=131">Chapter 6</a>).</p> <p>The SRES scenarios were developed as quantitative interpretations of the four alternative storylines that represent possible futures with different combinations of driving forces. These broad scenario families are broken down further into seven scenario groups<a href="index.php?idp=fn6#2" onclick="showFootnote(6,2); return false;"><sup>2</sup></a>, used here to classify the input driving forces (see also <a href="index.php?idp=112#tbl420">Table 4-20</a> in <a href="index.php?idp=89">Chapter 4</a>).</p> <p>The scenario outputs of most interest are emissions of GHGs, SO<small><sub>2</sub></small> , and other radiatively important gases. However, the categorization of scenarios based on emissions of multiple gases is quite difficult. All gases that contribute to radiative forcing should be considered, but methods of combining gases such as the use of global warming potentials (GWP) are appropriate only for near-term GHG inventories<a href="index.php?idp=fn6#3" onclick="showFootnote(6,3); return false;"><sup>3</sup></a>. In addition, emission trajectories may display different dynamics, from monotonic increases to non-linear trajectories in which a subsequent decline from a maximum occurs. This particularly diminishes the significance of a focus on any given year, such as 2100. In light of these difficulties, the classification approach presented here uses cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions between 1990 and 2100. CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> is the dominant GHG and cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions are expected to be roughly proportional to CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> radiative forcing over the time scale considered (Houghton et al. 1996).</p> <p>Total cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions from the 40 SRES scenarios fall into the range from 773 to 2538 gigatonnes of carbon (GtC) with a median of 1509 GtC. To represent this range, the scenario classification uses four intervals:</p> 
 <ul> 
  <li> 
   <table width="350" border="1" cellpadding="4" align="right"> 
    <tbody>
     <tr> 
      <td> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p><a href="index.php?idp=5-1"><img src="images/5-1.gif" width="350" height="214" border="0"></a></p> <p><b>Figure 5-1</b>: Global cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions in the 40 SRES scenarios, classified into four scenario families (each denoted by a different color code: A1, red; A2, brown; B1, green; B2, blue). Marker scenarios are shown with thick lines without ticks, globally harmonized scenarios with thin lines, and non-harmonized scenarios with thin, dotted lines. Black lines show percentiles, means, and medians for the 40 SRES scenarios. For numbers on the two additional illustrative scenarios A1FI and A1T see <a href="index.php?idp=164">Appendix VII</a>.</p> </td> 
     </tr> 
    </tbody>
   </table> <a name="fig51"></a>Less than 1100 GtC (low). </li> 
  <li>Between 1100 and 1450 GtC (medium-low). </li> 
  <li>Between 1450 and 1800 GtC (medium-high). </li> 
  <li>Greater than 1800 GtC (high).</li> 
 </ul> <p>Each CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> interval contains multiple scenarios and scenarios from more than one family. Each category also includes one of the four marker scenarios. <a href="index.php?idp=115#fig51">Figure 5-1</a> shows how cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions from the 40 SRES scenarios fit within the selected emission intervals.</p> <p><a href="index.php?idp=115#tbl52">Table 5-2</a> provides an overview of this scenario classification and links the scenario outcomes with factors that drive them, organized by family and scenario group (see also <a href="index.php?idp=112#tbl420">Table 4-20</a>). The rows in <a href="#tbl52">Table 5-2</a> represent the emission categories, while the columns represent the scenario families. The analysis of <a href="#tbl52">Table 5-2</a> reveals two key results:</p> 
 <ul> 
  <li>Similar future cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions may emerge from different sets of driving forces; </li> 
  <li>Conversely, similar future states of the world with respect to socio-economic development may yield different outcomes in terms of cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions.</li> 
 </ul> <p>Similar cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions can be attained in very different social, economic, and technological circumstances. High emission levels of the A2 marker scenario (A2-ASF) are also attained in all the A1 family scenarios with high fossil-fuel use (A1C and A1G groups), for example in A1G-MiniCAM. Medium-high emissions are attained in most of the A1 group scenarios (including the A1B marker, A1B-AIM), but also in scenarios from the B2 scenario family with high fossil-fuel use (e.g., B2-ASF). Medium-low emissions, which are characteristic of the B2 family, including the B2 marker (B2- MESSAGE), are also attained in the A2-A1-MiniCAM scenario, which illustrates the transition between the A2 and A1 families. Finally, low emission levels result from almost all the B1 family scenarios (including the B1 marker, B1-IMAGE) as well as from scenarios that belong to the A1T high-technology scenario group (e.g., A1T-MARIA). In <a href="index.php?idp=115#tbl52">Table 5-2</a>, italics are used for examples of scenarios within each emission category that illustrate alternative ways to achieve cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions similar to those of the marker scenarios.</p> <b><br> <a name="tbl52"></a></b> 
 <table border="0" cellpadding="4" align="center"> 
  <tbody>
   <tr> 
    <td colspan="8"><b><a name="tbl52">Table 5-2</a></b>: Scenario classification according to scenario family and cumulative total carbon dioxide emissions (fossil, industrial, and net deforestation) from 1990 to 2100. Markers are in bold print, the two additional illustrative scenarios of the A1 scenario group (see <a href="index.php?idp=fn6#2" onclick="showFootnote(6,2); return false;">footnote 2</a> of text) in italics; all harmonized scenarios have shaded background; and examples of scenarios with similar CO emissions (see text) are underlined.</td> 
   </tr> 
   <tr> 
    <td colspan="8"> <b>Cumulative Carbon Emission 1990-2100</b> </td> 
   </tr> 
   <tr>

     <hr> </td> 
   </tr> 
   <tr>

      <b>B1</b> 
     </div></td>

     <div align="left">
      <b>B2</b> 
     </div></td>

   <tr> 
    <td colspan="8"> 
     <hr> </td> 
   </tr> 
   <tr> 
    <td><b>Scenario Group</b></td> 
    <td><b>A1C</b></td> 
    <td><b>A1G</b></td> 
    <td><b>A1B</b></td> 
    <td><b>A1T</b></td>

  <tbody>
   <tr> 
    <td> <h2>5.1 Introduction</h2> <p>In this chapter emission estimates for radiatively important gases generated in 40 Special Report on Emission Scenarios (SRES) scenarios are present. These gases are carbon dioxide (CO<sub><small>2</small></sub>), methane (CH<small><sub>4</sub></small> ), nitrous oxide (N<small><sub>2</sub></small>O), nitrogen oxides (NO<sup>x</sup>), carbon monoxide (CO), non-methane volatile organic compounds (NMVOCs), sulfur dioxide (SO<small><sub>2</sub></small> ), chlorofluoro-carbons (CFCs) and hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFCs)<a href="index.php?idp=fn6#1" onclick="showFootnote(6,1); return false;"><sup>1</sup></a>, hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), and sulfur hexafluoride (SF<small><sub>6</sub></small> ) (see <a href="#tbl51">Table 5-1</a>). Emission estimates presented here span the interval from 1990 to 2100 at the global level and at the level of four SRES macro-regions (OECD90, REF, ASIA, and ALM; see <a href="index.php?idp=150">Appendix IV</a>). In addition, sulfur emission estimates are presented in the regional gridded format to assist in quantifying the effects at the local level. Links between emissions and the underlying driving forces presented in <a href="index.php?idp=89">Chapter 4</a> are illustrated also.</p> <b><br> <a name="tbl51"></a></b> 
     <table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="2" align="center"> 
      <tbody>
       <tr> 
        <td colspan="9"><b>Table 5- 1</b>: Overview of greenhouse gases (GHGs), ozone precursors, and sulfur emissions for the SRES scenario groups. Numbers are for the four markers and (in brackets) for the range across all scenarios from the same scenario group (standardized emissions, see also <a href="index.php?idp=fn6#2" onclick="showFootnote(6,2); return false;">footnote 2</a>).</td>

     </table> <p><br> As a result of differences in modeling and estimation approaches, base-year (1990) emission values in SRES scenarios developed using different models show substantial variation. To facilitate both use of the scenarios and comparisons across scenarios and families, base-year emissions in all 40 SRES scenarios were standardized using one common set of values (see <a href="index.php?idp=115#box51">Box 5-1</a>). With a few clearly indicated exceptions, only standardized emission values are discussed in this chapter. A complete set of standardized emissions, along with other quantitative scenario information, is provided in <a href="index.php?idp=164">Appendix VII</a>.</p> <b><br> <a name="box51"></a></b> 
     <table border="1" cellpadding="4" align="center"> 
      <tbody>
       <tr> 
        <td> <p><b>Box 5-1: Scenario Standardization</b></p> <p>One of the primary reasons for developing emissions scenarios is to enable coordinated studies of climate change, climate impacts, and mitigation options and strategies. With the multi-model approach used in the SRES process, 1990 and 2000 emissions do not agree in scenarios developed using different models. In addition, even with agreed reference values, it is time consuming and often impractical to fine-tune most integrated assessment models to reproduce a particular desired result. </p> <p>Nevertheless, differences in the base year and 2000 emissions may lead to confusion among the scenario users. Therefore, the 1990 and 2000 emission estimates were standardized in all the SRES scenarios, with emissions diverging after the year 2000. The procedure for selecting 1990 and 2000 emission values and the subsequent adjustments to scenario emissions are described in this box.</p> <p> The standardized scenarios share the same values for emissions in both 1990 and 2000. Emissions for the year 2000 are, of course, not yet known and 1990 emissions are also uncertain. The 1990 and 2000 emission estimates for all gases, except SO<small><sub>2</sub></small> , were set to be equal to the averages of initial values in the unadjusted four marker scenarios. This was carried out at the four-region level, and summed to obtain the standardized global totals. The resultant estimates are within relevant uncertainty ranges for each substance, but should not be interpreted as "endorsed" by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) to represent values for either global or regional emissions. Rather, they are the standardized base-year estimates used for the emissions scenarios. </p> <p>From 2000 to 2100, emissions in all the scenarios (except CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions from land-use and SO<small><sub>2</sub></small> emissions) were adjusted by applying a constant offset equal to the difference between the standardized 2000 value and the scenario-specific 2000 value. The purpose was to smooth scenario trajectories between 2000 and 2010. </p> <p>This procedure results in small distortions for those emissions that rise with time, or at least that do not ultimately decrease by a large amount as compared to the base year. However, for emissions that fall significantly over time, such as those from deforestation or of SO<small><sub>2</sub></small> , this procedure can cause more significant distortions and can even change the sign of the emission estimates at later times (i.e., change positive emission estimates into negative ones and vice versa). To avoid these distortions, for the aforementioned emissions, the year 2000 offset was reduced by 10% per decade, cumulatively, to make the offset zero by the year 2100. This allows preservation of the shape of emission trajectories and still ensures the 2000 standardization. </p> <p>The non-standardized scenario values are available from the modeling teams upon request, although the standardized values should be used for most purposes.</p> </td> 
       </tr> 
      </tbody>
     </table> <p><br> The first section in this chapter presents a "roadmap" that serves as an orientation to the 40 SRES scenarios. The roadmap gives a simple taxonomy that compares input parameters, as represented by the four scenario families, and emission outputs, as represented by the 1990 to 2100 cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions. The subsequent sections discuss in detail emissions of each gas over the next 100 years to 2100.</p> <h2>5.2. Roadmap to the Scenarios<a name="52"></a></h2> <p>A classification scheme is presented here to assist the reader in understanding the links between driving forces and scenario outputs. This scheme can also be used to help select appropriate scenarios for further analysis (see <a href="index.php?idp=131">Chapter 6</a>).</p> <p>The SRES scenarios were developed as quantitative interpretations of the four alternative storylines that represent possible futures with different combinations of driving forces. These broad scenario families are broken down further into seven scenario groups<a href="index.php?idp=fn6#2" onclick="showFootnote(6,2); return false;"><sup>2</sup></a>, used here to classify the input driving forces (see also <a href="index.php?idp=112#tbl420">Table 4-20</a> in <a href="index.php?idp=89">Chapter 4</a>).</p> <p>The scenario outputs of most interest are emissions of GHGs, SO<small><sub>2</sub></small> , and other radiatively important gases. However, the categorization of scenarios based on emissions of multiple gases is quite difficult. All gases that contribute to radiative forcing should be considered, but methods of combining gases such as the use of global warming potentials (GWP) are appropriate only for near-term GHG inventories<a href="index.php?idp=fn6#3" onclick="showFootnote(6,3); return false;"><sup>3</sup></a>. In addition, emission trajectories may display different dynamics, from monotonic increases to non-linear trajectories in which a subsequent decline from a maximum occurs. This particularly diminishes the significance of a focus on any given year, such as 2100. In light of these difficulties, the classification approach presented here uses cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions between 1990 and 2100. CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> is the dominant GHG and cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions are expected to be roughly proportional to CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> radiative forcing over the time scale considered (Houghton et al. 1996).</p> <p>Total cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions from the 40 SRES scenarios fall into the range from 773 to 2538 gigatonnes of carbon (GtC) with a median of 1509 GtC. To represent this range, the scenario classification uses four intervals:</p> 
     <ul> 
      <li> 
       <table width="350" border="1" cellpadding="4" align="right"> 
        <tbody>
         <tr> 
          <td> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p><a href="index.php?idp=5-1"><img src="images/5-1.gif" width="350" height="214" border="0"></a></p> <p><b>Figure 5-1</b>: Global cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions in the 40 SRES scenarios, classified into four scenario families (each denoted by a different color code: A1, red; A2, brown; B1, green; B2, blue). Marker scenarios are shown with thick lines without ticks, globally harmonized scenarios with thin lines, and non-harmonized scenarios with thin, dotted lines. Black lines show percentiles, means, and medians for the 40 SRES scenarios. For numbers on the two additional illustrative scenarios A1FI and A1T see <a href="index.php?idp=164">Appendix VII</a>.</p> </td> 
         </tr> 
        </tbody>
       </table> <a name="fig51"></a>Less than 1100 GtC (low). </li> 
      <li>Between 1100 and 1450 GtC (medium-low). </li> 
      <li>Between 1450 and 1800 GtC (medium-high). </li> 
      <li>Greater than 1800 GtC (high).</li> 
     </ul> <p>Each CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> interval contains multiple scenarios and scenarios from more than one family. Each category also includes one of the four marker scenarios. <a href="index.php?idp=115#fig51">Figure 5-1</a> shows how cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions from the 40 SRES scenarios fit within the selected emission intervals.</p> <p><a href="index.php?idp=115#tbl52">Table 5-2</a> provides an overview of this scenario classification and links the scenario outcomes with factors that drive them, organized by family and scenario group (see also <a href="index.php?idp=112#tbl420">Table 4-20</a>). The rows in <a href="#tbl52">Table 5-2</a> represent the emission categories, while the columns represent the scenario families. The analysis of <a href="#tbl52">Table 5-2</a> reveals two key results:</p> 
     <ul> 
      <li>Similar future cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions may emerge from different sets of driving forces; </li> 
      <li>Conversely, similar future states of the world with respect to socio-economic development may yield different outcomes in terms of cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions.</li> 
     </ul> <p>Similar cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions can be attained in very different social, economic, and technological circumstances. High emission levels of the A2 marker scenario (A2-ASF) are also attained in all the A1 family scenarios with high fossil-fuel use (A1C and A1G groups), for example in A1G-MiniCAM. Medium-high emissions are attained in most of the A1 group scenarios (including the A1B marker, A1B-AIM), but also in scenarios from the B2 scenario family with high fossil-fuel use (e.g., B2-ASF). Medium-low emissions, which are characteristic of the B2 family, including the B2 marker (B2- MESSAGE), are also attained in the A2-A1-MiniCAM scenario, which illustrates the transition between the A2 and A1 families. Finally, low emission levels result from almost all the B1 family scenarios (including the B1 marker, B1-IMAGE) as well as from scenarios that belong to the A1T high-technology scenario group (e.g., A1T-MARIA). In <a href="index.php?idp=115#tbl52">Table 5-2</a>, italics are used for examples of scenarios within each emission category that illustrate alternative ways to achieve cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions similar to those of the marker scenarios.</p> <b><br> <a name="tbl52"></a></b> 
     <table border="0" cellpadding="4" align="center"> 
      <tbody>
       <tr> 
        <td colspan="8"><b><a name="tbl52">Table 5-2</a></b>: Scenario classification according to scenario family and cumulative total carbon dioxide emissions (fossil, industrial, and net deforestation) from 1990 to 2100. Markers are in bold print, the two additional illustrative scenarios of the A1 scenario group (see <a href="index.php?idp=fn6#2" onclick="showFootnote(6,2); return false;">footnote 2</a> of text) in italics; all harmonized scenarios have shaded background; and examples of scenarios with similar CO emissions (see text) are underlined.</td>

Mon Jun 29 14:06:06 CEST 2020: <td> <h2>5.1 Introduction</h2> <p>In this chapter emission estimates for radiatively important gases generated in 40 Special Report on Emission Scenarios (SRES) scenarios are present. These gases are carbon dioxide (CO<sub><small>2</small></sub>), methane (CH<small><sub>4</sub></small> ), nitrous oxide (N<small><sub>2</sub></small>O), nitrogen oxides (NO<sup>x</sup>), carbon monoxide (CO), non-methane volatile organic compounds (NMVOCs), sulfur dioxide (SO<small><sub>2</sub></small> ), chlorofluoro-carbons (CFCs) and hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFCs)<a href="index.php?idp=fn6#1" onclick="showFootnote(6,1); return false;"><sup>1</sup></a>, hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), and sulfur hexafluoride (SF<small><sub>6</sub></small> ) (see <a href="#tbl51">Table 5-1</a>). Emission estimates presented here span the interval from 1990 to 2100 at the global level and at the level of four SRES macro-regions (OECD90, REF, ASIA, and ALM; see <a href="index.php?idp=150">Appendix IV</a>). In addition, sulfur emission estimates are presented in the regional gridded format to assist in quantifying the effects at the local level. Links between emissions and the underlying driving forces presented in <a href="index.php?idp=89">Chapter 4</a> are illustrated also.</p> <b><br> <a name="tbl51"></a></b> 
 <table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="2" align="center">

  </tbody>
 </table> <p><br> As a result of differences in modeling and estimation approaches, base-year (1990) emission values in SRES scenarios developed using different models show substantial variation. To facilitate both use of the scenarios and comparisons across scenarios and families, base-year emissions in all 40 SRES scenarios were standardized using one common set of values (see <a href="index.php?idp=115#box51">Box 5-1</a>). With a few clearly indicated exceptions, only standardized emission values are discussed in this chapter. A complete set of standardized emissions, along with other quantitative scenario information, is provided in <a href="index.php?idp=164">Appendix VII</a>.</p> <b><br> <a name="box51"></a></b> 
 <table border="1" cellpadding="4" align="center"> 
  <tbody>
   <tr> 
    <td> <p><b>Box 5-1: Scenario Standardization</b></p> <p>One of the primary reasons for developing emissions scenarios is to enable coordinated studies of climate change, climate impacts, and mitigation options and strategies. With the multi-model approach used in the SRES process, 1990 and 2000 emissions do not agree in scenarios developed using different models. In addition, even with agreed reference values, it is time consuming and often impractical to fine-tune most integrated assessment models to reproduce a particular desired result. </p> <p>Nevertheless, differences in the base year and 2000 emissions may lead to confusion among the scenario users. Therefore, the 1990 and 2000 emission estimates were standardized in all the SRES scenarios, with emissions diverging after the year 2000. The procedure for selecting 1990 and 2000 emission values and the subsequent adjustments to scenario emissions are described in this box.</p> <p> The standardized scenarios share the same values for emissions in both 1990 and 2000. Emissions for the year 2000 are, of course, not yet known and 1990 emissions are also uncertain. The 1990 and 2000 emission estimates for all gases, except SO<small><sub>2</sub></small> , were set to be equal to the averages of initial values in the unadjusted four marker scenarios. This was carried out at the four-region level, and summed to obtain the standardized global totals. The resultant estimates are within relevant uncertainty ranges for each substance, but should not be interpreted as "endorsed" by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) to represent values for either global or regional emissions. Rather, they are the standardized base-year estimates used for the emissions scenarios. </p> <p>From 2000 to 2100, emissions in all the scenarios (except CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions from land-use and SO<small><sub>2</sub></small> emissions) were adjusted by applying a constant offset equal to the difference between the standardized 2000 value and the scenario-specific 2000 value. The purpose was to smooth scenario trajectories between 2000 and 2010. </p> <p>This procedure results in small distortions for those emissions that rise with time, or at least that do not ultimately decrease by a large amount as compared to the base year. However, for emissions that fall significantly over time, such as those from deforestation or of SO<small><sub>2</sub></small> , this procedure can cause more significant distortions and can even change the sign of the emission estimates at later times (i.e., change positive emission estimates into negative ones and vice versa). To avoid these distortions, for the aforementioned emissions, the year 2000 offset was reduced by 10% per decade, cumulatively, to make the offset zero by the year 2100. This allows preservation of the shape of emission trajectories and still ensures the 2000 standardization. </p> <p>The non-standardized scenario values are available from the modeling teams upon request, although the standardized values should be used for most purposes.</p> </td> 
   </tr> 
  </tbody>
 </table> <p><br> The first section in this chapter presents a "roadmap" that serves as an orientation to the 40 SRES scenarios. The roadmap gives a simple taxonomy that compares input parameters, as represented by the four scenario families, and emission outputs, as represented by the 1990 to 2100 cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions. The subsequent sections discuss in detail emissions of each gas over the next 100 years to 2100.</p> <h2>5.2. Roadmap to the Scenarios<a name="52"></a></h2> <p>A classification scheme is presented here to assist the reader in understanding the links between driving forces and scenario outputs. This scheme can also be used to help select appropriate scenarios for further analysis (see <a href="index.php?idp=131">Chapter 6</a>).</p> <p>The SRES scenarios were developed as quantitative interpretations of the four alternative storylines that represent possible futures with different combinations of driving forces. These broad scenario families are broken down further into seven scenario groups<a href="index.php?idp=fn6#2" onclick="showFootnote(6,2); return false;"><sup>2</sup></a>, used here to classify the input driving forces (see also <a href="index.php?idp=112#tbl420">Table 4-20</a> in <a href="index.php?idp=89">Chapter 4</a>).</p> <p>The scenario outputs of most interest are emissions of GHGs, SO<small><sub>2</sub></small> , and other radiatively important gases. However, the categorization of scenarios based on emissions of multiple gases is quite difficult. All gases that contribute to radiative forcing should be considered, but methods of combining gases such as the use of global warming potentials (GWP) are appropriate only for near-term GHG inventories<a href="index.php?idp=fn6#3" onclick="showFootnote(6,3); return false;"><sup>3</sup></a>. In addition, emission trajectories may display different dynamics, from monotonic increases to non-linear trajectories in which a subsequent decline from a maximum occurs. This particularly diminishes the significance of a focus on any given year, such as 2100. In light of these difficulties, the classification approach presented here uses cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions between 1990 and 2100. CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> is the dominant GHG and cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions are expected to be roughly proportional to CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> radiative forcing over the time scale considered (Houghton et al. 1996).</p> <p>Total cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions from the 40 SRES scenarios fall into the range from 773 to 2538 gigatonnes of carbon (GtC) with a median of 1509 GtC. To represent this range, the scenario classification uses four intervals:</p> 
 <ul> 
  <li> 
   <table width="350" border="1" cellpadding="4" align="right"> 
    <tbody>
     <tr> 
      <td> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p><a href="index.php?idp=5-1"><img src="images/5-1.gif" width="350" height="214" border="0"></a></p> <p><b>Figure 5-1</b>: Global cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions in the 40 SRES scenarios, classified into four scenario families (each denoted by a different color code: A1, red; A2, brown; B1, green; B2, blue). Marker scenarios are shown with thick lines without ticks, globally harmonized scenarios with thin lines, and non-harmonized scenarios with thin, dotted lines. Black lines show percentiles, means, and medians for the 40 SRES scenarios. For numbers on the two additional illustrative scenarios A1FI and A1T see <a href="index.php?idp=164">Appendix VII</a>.</p> </td> 
     </tr> 
    </tbody>
   </table> <a name="fig51"></a>Less than 1100 GtC (low). </li> 
  <li>Between 1100 and 1450 GtC (medium-low). </li> 
  <li>Between 1450 and 1800 GtC (medium-high). </li> 
  <li>Greater than 1800 GtC (high).</li> 
 </ul> <p>Each CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> interval contains multiple scenarios and scenarios from more than one family. Each category also includes one of the four marker scenarios. <a href="index.php?idp=115#fig51">Figure 5-1</a> shows how cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions from the 40 SRES scenarios fit within the selected emission intervals.</p> <p><a href="index.php?idp=115#tbl52">Table 5-2</a> provides an overview of this scenario classification and links the scenario outcomes with factors that drive them, organized by family and scenario group (see also <a href="index.php?idp=112#tbl420">Table 4-20</a>). The rows in <a href="#tbl52">Table 5-2</a> represent the emission categories, while the columns represent the scenario families. The analysis of <a href="#tbl52">Table 5-2</a> reveals two key results:</p> 
 <ul> 
  <li>Similar future cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions may emerge from different sets of driving forces; </li> 
  <li>Conversely, similar future states of the world with respect to socio-economic development may yield different outcomes in terms of cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions.</li> 
 </ul> <p>Similar cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions can be attained in very different social, economic, and technological circumstances. High emission levels of the A2 marker scenario (A2-ASF) are also attained in all the A1 family scenarios with high fossil-fuel use (A1C and A1G groups), for example in A1G-MiniCAM. Medium-high emissions are attained in most of the A1 group scenarios (including the A1B marker, A1B-AIM), but also in scenarios from the B2 scenario family with high fossil-fuel use (e.g., B2-ASF). Medium-low emissions, which are characteristic of the B2 family, including the B2 marker (B2- MESSAGE), are also attained in the A2-A1-MiniCAM scenario, which illustrates the transition between the A2 and A1 families. Finally, low emission levels result from almost all the B1 family scenarios (including the B1 marker, B1-IMAGE) as well as from scenarios that belong to the A1T high-technology scenario group (e.g., A1T-MARIA). In <a href="index.php?idp=115#tbl52">Table 5-2</a>, italics are used for examples of scenarios within each emission category that illustrate alternative ways to achieve cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions similar to those of the marker scenarios.</p> <b><br> <a name="tbl52"></a></b> 
 <table border="0" cellpadding="4" align="center"> 
  <tbody>

Mon Jun 29 14:06:06 CEST 2020: <td> <h2>5.1 Introduction</h2> <p>In this chapter emission estimates for radiatively important gases generated in 40 Special Report on Emission Scenarios (SRES) scenarios are present. These gases are carbon dioxide (CO<sub><small>2</small></sub>), methane (CH<small><sub>4</sub></small> ), nitrous oxide (N<small><sub>2</sub></small>O), nitrogen oxides (NO<sup>x</sup>), carbon monoxide (CO), non-methane volatile organic compounds (NMVOCs), sulfur dioxide (SO<small><sub>2</sub></small> ), chlorofluoro-carbons (CFCs) and hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFCs)<a href="index.php?idp=fn6#1" onclick="showFootnote(6,1); return false;"><sup>1</sup></a>, hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), and sulfur hexafluoride (SF<small><sub>6</sub></small> ) (see <a href="#tbl51">Table 5-1</a>). Emission estimates presented here span the interval from 1990 to 2100 at the global level and at the level of four SRES macro-regions (OECD90, REF, ASIA, and ALM; see <a href="index.php?idp=150">Appendix IV</a>). In addition, sulfur emission estimates are presented in the regional gridded format to assist in quantifying the effects at the local level. Links between emissions and the underlying driving forces presented in <a href="index.php?idp=89">Chapter 4</a> are illustrated also.</p> <b><br> <a name="tbl51"></a></b> 
 <table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="2" align="center"> 
  <tbody>
   <tr> 
    <td colspan="9"><b>Table 5- 1</b>: Overview of greenhouse gases (GHGs), ozone precursors, and sulfur emissions for the SRES scenario groups. Numbers are for the four markers and (in brackets) for the range across all scenarios from the same scenario group (standardized emissions, see also <a href="index.php?idp=fn6#2" onclick="showFootnote(6,2); return false;">footnote 2</a>).</td> 
   </tr>

      <font size="-1">363 (363- 1871)</font> 
     </div></td>

   <tr> 
    <td><font size="-1"><b>B2</b></font></td> 
    <td width="12%" bgcolor="#f0f0f0"> 
     <div align="right">
      <font size="-1">13.3 (10.8- 21.8)</font> 
     </div></td>

  </tbody>
 </table> <p><br> As a result of differences in modeling and estimation approaches, base-year (1990) emission values in SRES scenarios developed using different models show substantial variation. To facilitate both use of the scenarios and comparisons across scenarios and families, base-year emissions in all 40 SRES scenarios were standardized using one common set of values (see <a href="index.php?idp=115#box51">Box 5-1</a>). With a few clearly indicated exceptions, only standardized emission values are discussed in this chapter. A complete set of standardized emissions, along with other quantitative scenario information, is provided in <a href="index.php?idp=164">Appendix VII</a>.</p> <b><br> <a name="box51"></a></b> 
 <table border="1" cellpadding="4" align="center"> 
  <tbody>
   <tr> 
    <td> <p><b>Box 5-1: Scenario Standardization</b></p> <p>One of the primary reasons for developing emissions scenarios is to enable coordinated studies of climate change, climate impacts, and mitigation options and strategies. With the multi-model approach used in the SRES process, 1990 and 2000 emissions do not agree in scenarios developed using different models. In addition, even with agreed reference values, it is time consuming and often impractical to fine-tune most integrated assessment models to reproduce a particular desired result. </p> <p>Nevertheless, differences in the base year and 2000 emissions may lead to confusion among the scenario users. Therefore, the 1990 and 2000 emission estimates were standardized in all the SRES scenarios, with emissions diverging after the year 2000. The procedure for selecting 1990 and 2000 emission values and the subsequent adjustments to scenario emissions are described in this box.</p> <p> The standardized scenarios share the same values for emissions in both 1990 and 2000. Emissions for the year 2000 are, of course, not yet known and 1990 emissions are also uncertain. The 1990 and 2000 emission estimates for all gases, except SO<small><sub>2</sub></small> , were set to be equal to the averages of initial values in the unadjusted four marker scenarios. This was carried out at the four-region level, and summed to obtain the standardized global totals. The resultant estimates are within relevant uncertainty ranges for each substance, but should not be interpreted as "endorsed" by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) to represent values for either global or regional emissions. Rather, they are the standardized base-year estimates used for the emissions scenarios. </p> <p>From 2000 to 2100, emissions in all the scenarios (except CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions from land-use and SO<small><sub>2</sub></small> emissions) were adjusted by applying a constant offset equal to the difference between the standardized 2000 value and the scenario-specific 2000 value. The purpose was to smooth scenario trajectories between 2000 and 2010. </p> <p>This procedure results in small distortions for those emissions that rise with time, or at least that do not ultimately decrease by a large amount as compared to the base year. However, for emissions that fall significantly over time, such as those from deforestation or of SO<small><sub>2</sub></small> , this procedure can cause more significant distortions and can even change the sign of the emission estimates at later times (i.e., change positive emission estimates into negative ones and vice versa). To avoid these distortions, for the aforementioned emissions, the year 2000 offset was reduced by 10% per decade, cumulatively, to make the offset zero by the year 2100. This allows preservation of the shape of emission trajectories and still ensures the 2000 standardization. </p> <p>The non-standardized scenario values are available from the modeling teams upon request, although the standardized values should be used for most purposes.</p> </td> 
   </tr> 
  </tbody>
 </table> <p><br> The first section in this chapter presents a "roadmap" that serves as an orientation to the 40 SRES scenarios. The roadmap gives a simple taxonomy that compares input parameters, as represented by the four scenario families, and emission outputs, as represented by the 1990 to 2100 cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions. The subsequent sections discuss in detail emissions of each gas over the next 100 years to 2100.</p> <h2>5.2. Roadmap to the Scenarios<a name="52"></a></h2> <p>A classification scheme is presented here to assist the reader in understanding the links between driving forces and scenario outputs. This scheme can also be used to help select appropriate scenarios for further analysis (see <a href="index.php?idp=131">Chapter 6</a>).</p> <p>The SRES scenarios were developed as quantitative interpretations of the four alternative storylines that represent possible futures with different combinations of driving forces. These broad scenario families are broken down further into seven scenario groups<a href="index.php?idp=fn6#2" onclick="showFootnote(6,2); return false;"><sup>2</sup></a>, used here to classify the input driving forces (see also <a href="index.php?idp=112#tbl420">Table 4-20</a> in <a href="index.php?idp=89">Chapter 4</a>).</p> <p>The scenario outputs of most interest are emissions of GHGs, SO<small><sub>2</sub></small> , and other radiatively important gases. However, the categorization of scenarios based on emissions of multiple gases is quite difficult. All gases that contribute to radiative forcing should be considered, but methods of combining gases such as the use of global warming potentials (GWP) are appropriate only for near-term GHG inventories<a href="index.php?idp=fn6#3" onclick="showFootnote(6,3); return false;"><sup>3</sup></a>. In addition, emission trajectories may display different dynamics, from monotonic increases to non-linear trajectories in which a subsequent decline from a maximum occurs. This particularly diminishes the significance of a focus on any given year, such as 2100. In light of these difficulties, the classification approach presented here uses cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions between 1990 and 2100. CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> is the dominant GHG and cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions are expected to be roughly proportional to CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> radiative forcing over the time scale considered (Houghton et al. 1996).</p> <p>Total cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions from the 40 SRES scenarios fall into the range from 773 to 2538 gigatonnes of carbon (GtC) with a median of 1509 GtC. To represent this range, the scenario classification uses four intervals:</p> 
 <ul> 
  <li> 
   <table width="350" border="1" cellpadding="4" align="right"> 
    <tbody>
     <tr> 
      <td> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p><a href="index.php?idp=5-1"><img src="images/5-1.gif" width="350" height="214" border="0"></a></p> <p><b>Figure 5-1</b>: Global cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions in the 40 SRES scenarios, classified into four scenario families (each denoted by a different color code: A1, red; A2, brown; B1, green; B2, blue). Marker scenarios are shown with thick lines without ticks, globally harmonized scenarios with thin lines, and non-harmonized scenarios with thin, dotted lines. Black lines show percentiles, means, and medians for the 40 SRES scenarios. For numbers on the two additional illustrative scenarios A1FI and A1T see <a href="index.php?idp=164">Appendix VII</a>.</p> </td> 
     </tr> 
    </tbody>
   </table> <a name="fig51"></a>Less than 1100 GtC (low). </li> 
  <li>Between 1100 and 1450 GtC (medium-low). </li> 
  <li>Between 1450 and 1800 GtC (medium-high). </li> 
  <li>Greater than 1800 GtC (high).</li> 
 </ul> <p>Each CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> interval contains multiple scenarios and scenarios from more than one family. Each category also includes one of the four marker scenarios. <a href="index.php?idp=115#fig51">Figure 5-1</a> shows how cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions from the 40 SRES scenarios fit within the selected emission intervals.</p> <p><a href="index.php?idp=115#tbl52">Table 5-2</a> provides an overview of this scenario classification and links the scenario outcomes with factors that drive them, organized by family and scenario group (see also <a href="index.php?idp=112#tbl420">Table 4-20</a>). The rows in <a href="#tbl52">Table 5-2</a> represent the emission categories, while the columns represent the scenario families. The analysis of <a href="#tbl52">Table 5-2</a> reveals two key results:</p> 
 <ul> 
  <li>Similar future cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions may emerge from different sets of driving forces; </li> 
  <li>Conversely, similar future states of the world with respect to socio-economic development may yield different outcomes in terms of cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions.</li> 
 </ul> <p>Similar cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions can be attained in very different social, economic, and technological circumstances. High emission levels of the A2 marker scenario (A2-ASF) are also attained in all the A1 family scenarios with high fossil-fuel use (A1C and A1G groups), for example in A1G-MiniCAM. Medium-high emissions are attained in most of the A1 group scenarios (including the A1B marker, A1B-AIM), but also in scenarios from the B2 scenario family with high fossil-fuel use (e.g., B2-ASF). Medium-low emissions, which are characteristic of the B2 family, including the B2 marker (B2- MESSAGE), are also attained in the A2-A1-MiniCAM scenario, which illustrates the transition between the A2 and A1 families. Finally, low emission levels result from almost all the B1 family scenarios (including the B1 marker, B1-IMAGE) as well as from scenarios that belong to the A1T high-technology scenario group (e.g., A1T-MARIA). In <a href="index.php?idp=115#tbl52">Table 5-2</a>, italics are used for examples of scenarios within each emission category that illustrate alternative ways to achieve cumulative CO<sub><small>2</small></sub> emissions similar to those of the marker scenarios.</p> <b><br> <a name="tbl52"></a></b> 
 <table border="0" cellpadding="4" align="center">

Mon Jun 29 14:25:16 CEST 2020: {"Scope 1":{"StartDate":"2018-01-01","CO2":749903,"EndDate":"2018-12-31"},"Company":{"company_text":"Ryder System, Inc. (Ryder), a Florida corporation founded in 1933, is a global leader in commercial fleet management and supply chain solutions. We\noperate primarily in three business segments: Fleet Management Solutions (FMS), Dedicated Transportation Services (DTS) and Supply Chain\nSolutions (SCS). Ryder has received significant awards and recognition from customers, leading transportation and logistics industry associations,\nbusiness and regulatory communities. Recent examples include: Forbes: America\u2019s Best Employers in Transportation and Logistics industry category\n(2016-2018); FORTUNE: World\u2019s Most Admired Companies Award in Trucking Industry (2016-2018); SupplyChainBrain - 100 Great Supply Chain\nPartners award (2017); Trucking HR Canada \u2013 Top Fleet Employers (2018); Carbon Disclosure Project Carbon Disclosure Leadership Index (2012,\n2015); Food Logistics: Top Green Providers award for green transportation and logistics solutions (2012 \u2013 2017); Inbound Logistics - top 75 Green\nSupply Chain Partners by Inbound Logistics (2009\u2013 2017); Supply & Demand Chain Executive: Green Supply Chain Award for meeting green or\nsustainable supply chain goals (2016-2017); 2020 Women on Boards W Company \u2013 Ryder was named a \u201CW\u201D company for having a board with more\nthan 20 percent women (2013, 2017); CivilianJobs.com\u2019s Most Valuable Employers (MVE) for Military (2013 - 2017); Florida Diversity Council: Most\nPowerful and Influential Women Award (2017); SmartWay Excellence Award (2017). The FMS business provides full service leasing (long-term),\ncommercial rental (short-term), as well as contract maintenance of trucks, tractors and trailers to customers principally in the U.S., Canada and the U.K.\nThe standard leasing business model offers customers different vehicle options (such as fuel-efficient or natural gas powered vehicle packages) with\nattractive financing mechanisms. Because of increased demand for vehicle efficiency and reliability, companies that own and manage their own fleet of\nvehicles have put greater emphasis on the quality of preventative maintenance for their vehicles. In addition, several trends have been increasing the\nneed for outsourcing: increased complexity and cost of buying and maintaining vehicles including technology, diagnostics, and training; labor issues\nincluding a shortage of qualified truck drivers and mechanics; as well as increased regulation \u2013 e.g. more expensive emission controls needed for EPA-\ncompliant engines - and enforcement of safety requirements. The Dedicated Transportation Service (DTS) option provides vehicles and drivers as part\nof a dedicate transportation solution in the US. Customers directly manage their overall freight movement but Ryder provides the equipment,\nmaintenance, and administrative services (including driver hiring, training, routing and scheduling, and fleet sizing) associated with maintaining the\n1\nRyder System, Inc. CDP Climate Change Questionnaire 2019 Friday, August 2, 2019\ncustomer\u2019s private fleet. This combination of services allow us to provide high service levels and the most efficient routing to lower fuel costs due to\nless idle time and fewer empty miles. A key difference between Dedicated Transportation Services and Full Service Lease is Ryder provides the drivers\nfor Dedicated. The SCS supply chain solution provides Distribution and Transportation Management services in North America and Asia. SCS\ncustomers are looking for a total integrated solution that includes managing outsourced vehicles, drivers, freight routing, IT integration, warehouse and\ndistribution management, as well as other logistics engineering services. SCS provides a wide range of services relating to a customer\u2019s distribution\noperations, from designing the distribution network to managing distribution facilities. Customers can more precisely align inbound and outbound\nshipments, synchronize returns with optimized fleet use and arrange backhauls to offset transportation costs and minimize empty miles that will directly\nhelp lowering GHG emissions. The SCS Transportation Management business offers services relating to all aspects of a customer\u2019s transportation\nnetwork. Ryder\u2019s transportation specialists provide shipment planning and execution, through a series of technological and web-based solutions.\nRyder published an updated Corporate Sustainability Report in accordance with the Global Reporting Initiative (GRI) Standards Core option with\ndetailed emissions and activity data (http:\/\/rydercsr.com). For the 2019 CDP response year, updates are provided to emission data (sections C6, C7\nand C8), but at the time of CDP publication, these were not fully audited. Ryder plans to resume full CDP reporting in 2020.","Company_id":"5eed2b474fe2bd337cd9ab6f","Name":"Ryder System"},"Scope 3":{"CO2":230126},"Scope 2":{"StartDate":"2018-01-01","CO2":118889,"EndDate":"2018-12-31","CO2 market based":117963},"ReportingStandard":"The Climate Registry","Source":{"URL":"https:\/\/ryder.com\/-\/media\/ryder\/ryder-global\/about-us\/sustainability\/adarydersysteminccdpclimatechangequestionnaire201920190802145748.pdf"}}

            <td><img src="../../../Organization_files/pixel.gif" alt="" width="12"></td>

            <td class="simple_title_bold" width="100%">Emissions Scenarios</td>

        <td align="center"> 
         <table width="720" border="0" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0">

            <td colspan="2"><img src="../../../img/pixel.gif" width="1" height="5"></td>

            <td colspan="2"> <font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="1"> <script language="JavaScript">

            <td valign="top"><br><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="1"> <script language="JavaScript">
		<!--
		PrevNext(156,501);
		//-->
		</script> </font> </td> 
            <td valign="top" align="right"> <font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="1"> <a href="https://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/publications_and_data_reports.htm">Other reports in this collection</a> </font> </td>

       <tr> 
        <td align="center"> <br> 
         <table width="720" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0"> 
          <tbody>
           <tr> 
            <td> <font class="simple_title">Appendix V: Database Description</font> <p>The SRES Emission Scenario Database (ESD) was developed to manage and access a large number of data sets and emissions scenarios documented in the literature. The SRES Terms of Reference call for the assessment of emissions scenarios in the literature (see <a href="index.php?idp=146">Appendix I</a>). The database was developed for SRES by the National Institute for Environmental Studies (NIES) of Japan and can be accessed via the ftp site <a href="http://www-cger.nies.go.jp/cger-e/db/ipcc.html" target="_blank">www-cger.nies.go.jp/cger-e/db/ipcc.html</a>. This section summarizes the database structure and the data collection for the database. <a href="index.php?idp=34">Chapter 2</a> gives further detail about the quantitative assessment of the scenarios in the database. At the time of writing the database included 416 scenarios from 171 sources.</p> <h2>V.1. Database Structure</h2> <p>The main purpose behind the development of the new database is to make it easier to manage and utilize the vast amounts of data related to emission scenarios of greenhouse gases (GHGs), which include carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>), nitrous oxide (N<sub>2</sub>O), methane (CH<sub>4</sub>), sulfur oxides (SO<sub>x</sub>), and related gases, (such as carbon monoxide (CO), nitrogen oxides (NO<sub>x</sub>), and hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs). The need for such a database is a function of both the increasing number of emission scenarios (because of increasing political and research interests in this topic) and the necessity to identify the strengths and weaknesses of current scenarios (to allow research to be focused on the most crucial or under-investigated areas).</p> <p>These emission scenarios have been quantified mainly using computer simulation models, which in turn utilize many assumptions on factors such as population growth, gross domestic product (GDP) growth, technology efficiency improvements, land-use changes, and the energy resource base. The assumptions used in incorporating these factors often differ between simulations, as do the actual factors represented in the simulations. As a result, the database was designed to organize and store the input assumptions behind the scenarios as well as GHG emissions and other output.</p> <p>Given the diversity of data types that must be accommodated, the database was designed with a relational database structure (using MS Access '97). The data represent large samples, and it is important that they be stored according to a structure that also allows the relationships between different data types to be represented and stored. A detailed description of the database structure is given in Morita and Lee (1998).</p> <p>Each individual data entry is stored in the DATAMOM. Using the relational structure, it is possible to call data from within any of four main fields (Source ID, Scenario ID, Region ID, or Variable) using a number of subcategories specific to the individual fields. For example, the Source ID data entry field has the following subcategories:</p> 
             <ul> 
              <li>Source ID (an abbreviated model or organization name with multiple data sets distinguished by the year of publication).</li> 
              <li>Authors (individual name or organization name).</li> 
              <li>Reference (publication in which the data are found).</li> 
              <li>Model (main simulation models).</li> 
              <li>Category (of simulation model, such as bottom-up or top-down, dynamic optimization of general equilibrium, etc.).</li> 
              <li>Update date (of the most recent publication).</li> 
              <li>Notes (if any).</li> 
             </ul> <p>Table V-1 briefly summarizes the subdivisions in the other key fields.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
             <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4"> 
              <tbody>
               <tr> 
                <td colspan="4"><i><b>Table V- 1:</b><a name="tblV1"></a> Overview of Subdivisions in Key Fields in the Scenario Database. The main data fields for the SRES ESD are shown for the field names that identify the scenario by reference and name of world region and variable type.</i></td> 
               </tr> 
               <tr> 
                <td colspan="4"> 
                 <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
               </tr> 
               <tr> 
                <td><b>Field Name</b></td> 
                <td colspan="2"><b>Subdivision (and brief description)</b></td> 
                <td>&nbsp;</td> 
               </tr> 
               <tr> 
                <td colspan="4"> 
                 <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
               </tr> 
               <tr valign="top"> 
                <td><i>Scenario</i></td> 
                <td><u>Scenario ID</u> <br> (For reference scenario, or specific name of scenario, if one exists)</td> 
                <td><u>Category</u> <br> (Of scenario: non- intervention, intervention, or uncertain( ty). Blank if scenario not identifiable. Non- intervention means a scenario with no reduction policies for carbon emission, but which might include policies on other GHGs)</td> 
                <td><u>Description:</u> <br> (Of scenarios storyline and main assumptions)</td> 
               </tr> 
               <tr valign="top"> 
                <td><i></i></td> 
                <td colspan="3"> 
                 <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
               </tr> 
               <tr valign="top"> 
                <td><i>Region</i></td> 
                <td colspan="2"> <p><u>Region ID</u><br> (Many scenarios use different names for the same region. These are converted into one unique Region ID. The full country name is used for national studies)</p> </td> 
                <td><u>Definition</u><br> (Of each Region ID)</td> 
               </tr> 
               <tr valign="top"> 
                <td><i></i></td> 
                <td colspan="3"> 
                 <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
               </tr> 
               <tr valign="top"> 
                <td><i>Variable</i></td> 
                <td><u>Description</u> <br> (Of each variable for each source)</td> 
                <td><u>Varable</u> <br> (A common variable name is used for the same data item when names vary among sources)</td> 
                <td><u>Unit</u></td> 
               </tr> 
               <tr> 
                <td colspan="4"> 
                 <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
               </tr> 
              </tbody>
             </table> <p><br> The database has the primary function of acting as a data storage tool, and as an interface that will allow the user easy access to the data sets contained therein. Thus, it only provides data, and analyses are conducted using other tools such as spreadsheets. However, the relational structure of the database makes it possible to call up comparable data sets across the key fields, giving maximum flexibility in manipulation, extraction, and presentation of all the data in the database. Similarly, there is great flexibility in importing new data, or making a data set from the database using combinations of specific sources, specific scenarios (or categories), specific regions, and specific variables. The extraction screen in <a href="index.php?idp=157#figV1">Figure V-1</a>, for example, shows the settings used to extract all information on all scenarios that are generated with the AIM Japan source model and to examine global sea level rise.</p> <p>The writing team recommends that this database or a new revised one should also be maintained by some institution in the future to facilitate comparisons and assessments of emissions scenarios. However, this would require additional resources.</p> </td> 
           </tr> 
          </tbody>
         </table> </td> 
       </tr> 
       <tr> 
        <td> <img src="../../../img/rainbow.jpg" width="750" height="1" vspace="12"></td> 
       </tr>

               <p><a href="index.php?idp=0">Table of contents</a></p> 
              </noscript> <script language="JavaScript">

      </script> <br> <a href="https://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/publications_and_data_reports.htm">Other reports in this collection</a> </font> </td> 
            <td align="right"> <p><a href="https://www.ipcc.ch/index.htm">IPCC Homepage</a></p> </td> 
           </tr>

        <td> <font class="simple_title">Appendix V: Database Description</font> <p>The SRES Emission Scenario Database (ESD) was developed to manage and access a large number of data sets and emissions scenarios documented in the literature. The SRES Terms of Reference call for the assessment of emissions scenarios in the literature (see <a href="index.php?idp=146">Appendix I</a>). The database was developed for SRES by the National Institute for Environmental Studies (NIES) of Japan and can be accessed via the ftp site <a href="http://www-cger.nies.go.jp/cger-e/db/ipcc.html" target="_blank">www-cger.nies.go.jp/cger-e/db/ipcc.html</a>. This section summarizes the database structure and the data collection for the database. <a href="index.php?idp=34">Chapter 2</a> gives further detail about the quantitative assessment of the scenarios in the database. At the time of writing the database included 416 scenarios from 171 sources.</p> <h2>V.1. Database Structure</h2> <p>The main purpose behind the development of the new database is to make it easier to manage and utilize the vast amounts of data related to emission scenarios of greenhouse gases (GHGs), which include carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>), nitrous oxide (N<sub>2</sub>O), methane (CH<sub>4</sub>), sulfur oxides (SO<sub>x</sub>), and related gases, (such as carbon monoxide (CO), nitrogen oxides (NO<sub>x</sub>), and hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs).  <table width="720" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0"> 
  <tbody>
   <tr> 
    <td> <font class="simple_title">Appendix V: Database Description</font> <p>The SRES Emission Scenario Database (ESD) was developed to manage and access a large number of data sets and emissions scenarios documented in the literature. The SRES Terms of Reference call for the assessment of emissions scenarios in the literature (see <a href="index.php?idp=146">Appendix I</a>). The database was developed for SRES by the National Institute for Environmental Studies (NIES) of Japan and can be accessed via the ftp site <a href="http://www-cger.nies.go.jp/cger-e/db/ipcc.html" target="_blank">www-cger.nies.go.jp/cger-e/db/ipcc.html</a>. This section summarizes the database structure and the data collection for the database. <a href="index.php?idp=34">Chapter 2</a> gives further detail about the quantitative assessment of the scenarios in the database. At the time of writing the database included 416 scenarios from 171 sources.</p> <h2>V.1. Database Structure</h2> <p>The main purpose behind the development of the new database is to make it easier to manage and utilize the vast amounts of data related to emission scenarios of greenhouse gases (GHGs), which include carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>), nitrous oxide (N<sub>2</sub>O), methane (CH<sub>4</sub>), sulfur oxides (SO<sub>x</sub>), and related gases, (such as carbon monoxide (CO), nitrogen oxides (NO<sub>x</sub>), and hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs). The need for such a database is a function of both the increasing number of emission scenarios (because of increasing political and research interests in this topic) and the necessity to identify the strengths and weaknesses of current scenarios (to allow research to be focused on the most crucial or under-investigated areas).</p> <p>These emission scenarios have been quantified mainly using computer simulation models, which in turn utilize many assumptions on factors such as population growth, gross domestic product (GDP) growth, technology efficiency improvements, land-use changes, and the energy resource base. The assumptions used in incorporating these factors often differ between simulations, as do the actual factors represented in the simulations. As a result, the database was designed to organize and store the input assumptions behind the scenarios as well as GHG emissions and other output.</p> <p>Given the diversity of data types that must be accommodated, the database was designed with a relational database structure (using MS Access '97). The data represent large samples, and it is important that they be stored according to a structure that also allows the relationships between different data types to be represented and stored. A detailed description of the database structure is given in Morita and Lee (1998).</p> <p>Each individual data entry is stored in the DATAMOM. Using the relational structure, it is possible to call data from within any of four main fields (Source ID, Scenario ID, Region ID, or Variable) using a number of subcategories specific to the individual fields. For example, the Source ID data entry field has the following subcategories:</p> 
     <ul> 
      <li>Source ID (an abbreviated model or organization name with multiple data sets distinguished by the year of publication).</li>

      <li>Reference (publication in which the data are found).</li>

      <li>Category (of simulation model, such as bottom-up or top-down, dynamic optimization of general equilibrium, etc.).</li> 
      <li>Update date (of the most recent publication).</li> 
      <li>Notes (if any).</li> 
     </ul> <p>Table V-1 briefly summarizes the subdivisions in the other key fields.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
     <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4"> 
      <tbody>
       <tr> 
        <td colspan="4"><i><b>Table V- 1:</b><a name="tblV1"></a> Overview of Subdivisions in Key Fields in the Scenario Database. The main data fields for the SRES ESD are shown for the field names that identify the scenario by reference and name of world region and variable type.</i></td> 
       </tr> 
       <tr>

        <td colspan="2"><b>Subdivision (and brief description)</b></td>

       </tr>

        <td colspan="4"> 
         <hr noshade size="1"> </td>

       </tr>

        <td colspan="2"> <p><u>Region ID</u><br> (Many scenarios use different names for the same region. These are converted into one unique Region ID. The full country name is used for national studies)</p> </td> 
        <td><u>Definition</u><br> (Of each Region ID)</td> 
       </tr> 
       <tr valign="top"> 
        <td><i></i></td> 
        <td colspan="3"> 
         <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
       </tr> 
       <tr valign="top"> 
        <td><i>Variable</i></td> 
        <td><u>Description</u> <br> (Of each variable for each source)</td> 
        <td><u>Varable</u> <br> (A common variable name is used for the same data item when names vary among sources)</td> 
        <td><u>Unit</u></td> 
       </tr> 
       <tr> 
        <td colspan="4"> 
         <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
       </tr> 
      </tbody>
     </table> <p><br> The database has the primary function of acting as a data storage tool, and as an interface that will allow the user easy access to the data sets contained therein. Thus, it only provides data, and analyses are conducted using other tools such as spreadsheets. However, the relational structure of the database makes it possible to call up comparable data sets across the key fields, giving maximum flexibility in manipulation, extraction, and presentation of all the data in the database. Similarly, there is great flexibility in importing new data, or making a data set from the database using combinations of specific sources, specific scenarios (or categories), specific regions, and specific variables. The extraction screen in <a href="index.php?idp=157#figV1">Figure V-1</a>, for example, shows the settings used to extract all information on all scenarios that are generated with the AIM Japan source model and to examine global sea level rise.</p> <p>The writing team recommends that this database or a new revised one should also be maintained by some institution in the future to facilitate comparisons and assessments of emissions scenarios. However, this would require additional resources.</p> </td> 
   </tr> 
  </tbody>
 </table> </td>
Mon Jun 29 14:25:45 CEST 2020: Invalid Data
Mon Jun 29 14:25:45 CEST 2020: Invalid Data, Trying again...
Mon Jun 29 14:25:45 CEST 2020: <td> <font class="simple_title">Appendix V: Database Description</font> <p>The SRES Emission Scenario Database (ESD) was developed to manage and access a large number of data sets and emissions scenarios documented in the literature. The SRES Terms of Reference call for the assessment of emissions scenarios in the literature (see <a href="index.php?idp=146">Appendix I</a>). The database was developed for SRES by the National Institute for Environmental Studies (NIES) of Japan and can be accessed via the ftp site <a href="http://www-cger.nies.go.jp/cger-e/db/ipcc.html" target="_blank">www-cger.nies.go.jp/cger-e/db/ipcc.html</a>. This section summarizes the database structure and the data collection for the database. <a href="index.php?idp=34">Chapter 2</a> gives further detail about the quantitative assessment of the scenarios in the database. At the time of writing the database included 416 scenarios from 171 sources.</p> <h2>V.1. Database Structure</h2> <p>The main purpose behind the development of the new database is to make it easier to manage and utilize the vast amounts of data related to emission scenarios of greenhouse gases (GHGs), which include carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>), nitrous oxide (N<sub>2</sub>O), methane (CH<sub>4</sub>), sulfur oxides (SO<sub>x</sub>), and related gases, (such as carbon monoxide (CO), nitrogen oxides (NO<sub>x</sub>), and hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs). The need for such a database is a function of both the increasing number of emission scenarios (because of increasing political and research interests in this topic) and the necessity to identify the strengths and weaknesses of current scenarios (to allow research to be focused on the most crucial or under-investigated areas).</p> <p>These emission scenarios have been quantified mainly using computer simulation models, which in turn utilize many assumptions on factors such as population growth, gross domestic product (GDP) growth, technology efficiency improvements, land-use changes, and the energy resource base. The assumptions used in incorporating these factors often differ between simulations, as do the actual factors represented in the simulations. As a result, the database was designed to organize and store the input assumptions behind the scenarios as well as GHG emissions and other output.</p> <p>Given the diversity of data types that must be accommodated, the database was designed with a relational database structure (using MS Access '97). The data represent large samples, and it is important that they be stored according to a structure that also allows the relationships between different data types to be represented and stored. A detailed description of the database structure is given in Morita and Lee (1998).</p> <p>Each individual data entry is stored in the DATAMOM. Using the relational structure, it is possible to call data from within any of four main fields (Source ID, Scenario ID, Region ID, or Variable) using a number of subcategories specific to the individual fields. For example, the Source ID data entry field has the following subcategories:</p> 
 <ul> 
  <li>Source ID (an abbreviated model or organization name with multiple data sets distinguished by the year of publication).</li> 
  <li>Authors (individual name or organization name).</li> 
  <li>Reference (publication in which the data are found).</li> 
  <li>Model (main simulation models).</li> 
  <li>Category (of simulation model, such as bottom-up or top-down, dynamic optimization of general equilibrium, etc.).</li> 
  <li>Update date (of the most recent publication).</li> 
  <li>Notes (if any).</li> 
 </ul> <p>Table V-1 briefly summarizes the subdivisions in the other key fields.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
 <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4"> 
  <tbody>
   <tr> 
    <td colspan="4"><i><b>Table V- 1:</b><a name="tblV1"></a> Overview of Subdivisions in Key Fields in the Scenario Database. The main data fields for the SRES ESD are shown for the field names that identify the scenario by reference and name of world region and variable type.</i></td> 
   </tr> 
   <tr> 
    <td colspan="4"> 
     <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
   </tr> 
   <tr> 
    <td><b>Field Name</b></td> 
    <td colspan="2"><b>Subdivision (and brief description)</b></td> 
    <td>&nbsp;</td> 
   </tr> 
   <tr> 
    <td colspan="4"> 
     <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
   </tr> 
   <tr valign="top"> 
    <td><i>Scenario</i></td> 
    <td><u>Scenario ID</u> <br> (For reference scenario, or specific name of scenario, if one exists)</td> 
    <td><u>Category</u> <br> (Of scenario: non- intervention, intervention, or uncertain( ty). Blank if scenario not identifiable. Non- intervention means a scenario with no reduction policies for carbon emission, but which might include policies on other GHGs)</td> 
    <td><u>Description:</u> <br> (Of scenarios storyline and main assumptions)</td> 
   </tr> 
   <tr valign="top"> 
    <td><i></i></td> 
    <td colspan="3"> 
     <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
   </tr> 
   <tr valign="top"> 
    <td><i>Region</i></td> 
    <td colspan="2"> <p><u>Region ID</u><br> (Many scenarios use different names for the same region. These are converted into one unique Region ID. The full country name is used for national studies)</p> </td> 
    <td><u>Definition</u><br> (Of each Region ID)</td> 
   </tr> 
   <tr valign="top"> 
    <td><i></i></td> 
    <td colspan="3"> 
     <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
   </tr> 
   <tr valign="top"> 
    <td><i>Variable</i></td> 
    <td><u>Description</u> <br> (Of each variable for each source)</td> 
    <td><u>Varable</u> <br> (A common variable name is used for the same data item when names vary among sources)</td> 
    <td><u>Unit</u></td> 
   </tr> 
   <tr> 
    <td colspan="4"> 
     <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
   </tr> 
  </tbody>
 </table> <p><br> The database has the primary function of acting as a data storage tool, and as an interface that will allow the user easy access to the data sets contained therein. Thus, it only provides data, and analyses are conducted using other tools such as spreadsheets. However, the relational structure of the database makes it possible to call up comparable data sets across the key fields, giving maximum flexibility in manipulation, extraction, and presentation of all the data in the database. Similarly, there is great flexibility in importing new data, or making a data set from the database using combinations of specific sources, specific scenarios (or categories), specific regions, and specific variables. The extraction screen in <a href="index.php?idp=157#figV1">Figure V-1</a>, for example, shows the settings used to extract all information on all scenarios that are generated with the AIM Japan source model and to examine global sea level rise.</p> <p>The writing team recommends that this database or a new revised one should also be maintained by some institution in the future to facilitate comparisons and assessments of emissions scenarios. However, this would require additional resources.</p> </td>
Mon Jun 29 14:25:45 CEST 2020: Invalid Data
