       <tr> 
        <td> <font class="simple_title">Appendix V: Database Description</font> <p>The SRES Emission Scenario Database (ESD) was developed to manage and access a large number of data sets and emissions scenarios documented in the literature. The SRES Terms of Reference call for the assessment of emissions scenarios in the literature (see <a href="index.php?idp=146">Appendix I</a>). The database was developed for SRES by the National Institute for Environmental Studies (NIES) of Japan and can be accessed via the ftp site <a href="http://www-cger.nies.go.jp/cger-e/db/ipcc.html" target="_blank">www-cger.nies.go.jp/cger-e/db/ipcc.html</a>. This section summarizes the database structure and the data collection for the database. <a href="index.php?idp=34">Chapter 2</a> gives further detail about the quantitative assessment of the scenarios in the database. At the time of writing the database included 416 scenarios from 171 sources.</p> <h2>V.1. Database Structure</h2> <p>The main purpose behind the development of the new database is to make it easier to manage and utilize the vast amounts of data related to emission scenarios of greenhouse gases (GHGs), which include carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>), nitrous oxide (N<sub>2</sub>O), methane (CH<sub>4</sub>), sulfur oxides (SO<sub>x</sub>), and related gases, (such as carbon monoxide (CO), nitrogen oxides (NO<sub>x</sub>), and hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs). The need for such a database is a function of both the increasing number of emission scenarios (because of increasing political and research interests in this topic) and the necessity to identify the strengths and weaknesses of current scenarios (to allow research to be focused on the most crucial or under-investigated areas).</p> <p>These emission scenarios have been quantified mainly using computer simulation models, which in turn utilize many assumptions on factors such as population growth, gross domestic product (GDP) growth, technology efficiency improvements, land-use changes, and the energy resource base. The assumptions used in incorporating these factors often differ between simulations, as do the actual factors represented in the simulations. As a result, the database was designed to organize and store the input assumptions behind the scenarios as well as GHG emissions and other output.</p> <p>Given the diversity of data types that must be accommodated, the database was designed with a relational database structure (using MS Access '97). The data represent large samples, and it is important that they be stored according to a structure that also allows the relationships between different data types to be represented and stored. A detailed description of the database structure is given in Morita and Lee (1998).</p> <p>Each individual data entry is stored in the DATAMOM. Using the relational structure, it is possible to call data from within any of four main fields (Source ID, Scenario ID, Region ID, or Variable) using a number of subcategories specific to the individual fields. For example, the Source ID data entry field has the following subcategories:</p> 
         <ul> 
          <li>Source ID (an abbreviated model or organization name with multiple data sets distinguished by the year of publication).</li> 
          <li>Authors (individual name or organization name).</li> 
          <li>Reference (publication in which the data are found).</li> 
          <li>Model (main simulation models).</li> 
          <li>Category (of simulation model, such as bottom-up or top-down, dynamic optimization of general equilibrium, etc.).</li> 
          <li>Update date (of the most recent publication).</li> 
          <li>Notes (if any).</li> 
         </ul> <p>Table V-1 briefly summarizes the subdivisions in the other key fields.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
         <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4"> 
          <tbody>
           <tr> 
            <td colspan="4"><i><b>Table V- 1:</b><a name="tblV1"></a> Overview of Subdivisions in Key Fields in the Scenario Database. The main data fields for the SRES ESD are shown for the field names that identify the scenario by reference and name of world region and variable type.</i></td> 
           </tr> 
           <tr> 
            <td colspan="4"> 
             <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
           </tr> 
           <tr> 
            <td><b>Field Name</b></td> 
            <td colspan="2"><b>Subdivision (and brief description)</b></td> 
            <td>&nbsp;</td> 
           </tr> 
           <tr> 
            <td colspan="4"> 
             <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
           </tr> 
           <tr valign="top"> 
            <td><i>Scenario</i></td> 
            <td><u>Scenario ID</u> <br> (For reference scenario, or specific name of scenario, if one exists)</td> 
            <td><u>Category</u> <br> (Of scenario: non- intervention, intervention, or uncertain( ty). Blank if scenario not identifiable. Non- intervention means a scenario with no reduction policies for carbon emission, but which might include policies on other GHGs)</td> 
            <td><u>Description:</u> <br> (Of scenarios storyline and main assumptions)</td> 
           </tr> 
           <tr valign="top"> 
            <td><i></i></td> 
            <td colspan="3"> 
             <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
           </tr> 
           <tr valign="top"> 
            <td><i>Region</i></td> 
            <td colspan="2"> <p><u>Region ID</u><br> (Many scenarios use different names for the same region. These are converted into one unique Region ID. The full country name is used for national studies)</p> </td> 
            <td><u>Definition</u><br> (Of each Region ID)</td> 
           </tr> 
           <tr valign="top"> 
            <td><i></i></td> 
            <td colspan="3"> 
             <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
           </tr> 
           <tr valign="top"> 
            <td><i>Variable</i></td> 
            <td><u>Description</u> <br> (Of each variable for each source)</td> 
            <td><u>Varable</u> <br> (A common variable name is used for the same data item when names vary among sources)</td> 
            <td><u>Unit</u></td> 
           </tr> 
           <tr> 
            <td colspan="4"> 
             <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
           </tr> 
          </tbody>
         </table> <p><br> The database has the primary function of acting as a data storage tool, and as an interface that will allow the user easy access to the data sets contained therein. Thus, it only provides data, and analyses are conducted using other tools such as spreadsheets. However, the relational structure of the database makes it possible to call up comparable data sets across the key fields, giving maximum flexibility in manipulation, extraction, and presentation of all the data in the database. Similarly, there is great flexibility in importing new data, or making a data set from the database using combinations of specific sources, specific scenarios (or categories), specific regions, and specific variables. The extraction screen in <a href="index.php?idp=157#figV1">Figure V-1</a>, for example, shows the settings used to extract all information on all scenarios that are generated with the AIM Japan source model and to examine global sea level rise.</p> <p>The writing team recommends that this database or a new revised one should also be maintained by some institution in the future to facilitate comparisons and assessments of emissions scenarios. However, this would require additional resources.</p> </td> 
       </tr> 
      </tbody>
     </table> </td> 
   </tr> 
   <tr> 
    <td> <img src="../../../img/rainbow.jpg" width="750" height="1" vspace="12"></td> 
   </tr> 
   <tr> 
    <td align="center"> 
     <table width="720" border="0" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0"> 
      <tbody>

Mon Jun 29 14:25:45 CEST 2020: <td align="center"> <br> 
 <table width="720" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0"> 
  <tbody>
   <tr> 
    <td> <font class="simple_title">Appendix V: Database Description</font> <p>The SRES Emission Scenario Database (ESD) was developed to manage and access a large number of data sets and emissions scenarios documented in the literature. The SRES Terms of Reference call for the assessment of emissions scenarios in the literature (see <a href="index.php?idp=146">Appendix I</a>). The database was developed for SRES by the National Institute for Environmental Studies (NIES) of Japan and can be accessed via the ftp site <a href="http://www-cger.nies.go.jp/cger-e/db/ipcc.html" target="_blank">www-cger.nies.go.jp/cger-e/db/ipcc.html</a>. This section summarizes the database structure and the data collection for the database. <a href="index.php?idp=34">Chapter 2</a> gives further detail about the quantitative assessment of the scenarios in the database. At the time of writing the database included 416 scenarios from 171 sources.</p> <h2>V.1. Database Structure</h2> <p>The main purpose behind the development of the new database is to make it easier to manage and utilize the vast amounts of data related to emission scenarios of greenhouse gases (GHGs), which include carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>), nitrous oxide (N<sub>2</sub>O), methane (CH<sub>4</sub>), sulfur oxides (SO<sub>x</sub>), and related gases, (such as carbon monoxide (CO), nitrogen oxides (NO<sub>x</sub>), and hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs). The need for such a database is a function of both the increasing number of emission scenarios (because of increasing political and research interests in this topic) and the necessity to identify the strengths and weaknesses of current scenarios (to allow research to be focused on the most crucial or under-investigated areas).</p> <p>These emission scenarios have been quantified mainly using computer simulation models, which in turn utilize many assumptions on factors such as population growth, gross domestic product (GDP) growth, technology efficiency improvements, land-use changes, and the energy resource base. The assumptions used in incorporating these factors often differ between simulations, as do the actual factors represented in the simulations. As a result, the database was designed to organize and store the input assumptions behind the scenarios as well as GHG emissions and other output.</p> <p>Given the diversity of data types that must be accommodated, the database was designed with a relational database structure (using MS Access '97). The data represent large samples, and it is important that they be stored according to a structure that also allows the relationships between different data types to be represented and stored. A detailed description of the database structure is given in Morita and Lee (1998).</p> <p>Each individual data entry is stored in the DATAMOM. Using the relational structure, it is possible to call data from within any of four main fields (Source ID, Scenario ID, Region ID, or Variable) using a number of subcategories specific to the individual fields. For example, the Source ID data entry field has the following subcategories:</p> 
     <ul> 
      <li>Source ID (an abbreviated model or organization name with multiple data sets distinguished by the year of publication).</li> 
      <li>Authors (individual name or organization name).</li> 
      <li>Reference (publication in which the data are found).</li> 
      <li>Model (main simulation models).</li> 
      <li>Category (of simulation model, such as bottom-up or top-down, dynamic optimization of general equilibrium, etc.).</li> 
      <li>Update date (of the most recent publication).</li> 
      <li>Notes (if any).</li> 
     </ul> <p>Table V-1 briefly summarizes the subdivisions in the other key fields.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
     <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4"> 
      <tbody>
       <tr> 
        <td colspan="4"><i><b>Table V- 1:</b><a name="tblV1"></a> Overview of Subdivisions in Key Fields in the Scenario Database. The main data fields for the SRES ESD are shown for the field names that identify the scenario by reference and name of world region and variable type.</i></td> 
       </tr> 
       <tr> 
        <td colspan="4"> 
         <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
       </tr> 
       <tr> 
        <td><b>Field Name</b></td> 
        <td colspan="2"><b>Subdivision (and brief description)</b></td> 
        <td>&nbsp;</td> 
       </tr> 
       <tr> 
        <td colspan="4"> 
         <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
       </tr> 
       <tr valign="top"> 
        <td><i>Scenario</i></td> 
        <td><u>Scenario ID</u> <br> (For reference scenario, or specific name of scenario, if one exists)</td> 
        <td><u>Category</u> <br> (Of scenario: non- intervention, intervention, or uncertain( ty). Blank if scenario not identifiable. Non- intervention means a scenario with no reduction policies for carbon emission, but which might include policies on other GHGs)</td> 
        <td><u>Description:</u> <br> (Of scenarios storyline and main assumptions)</td> 
       </tr> 
       <tr valign="top"> 
        <td><i></i></td> 
        <td colspan="3"> 
         <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
       </tr> 
       <tr valign="top"> 
        <td><i>Region</i></td> 
        <td colspan="2"> <p><u>Region ID</u><br> (Many scenarios use different names for the same region. These are converted into one unique Region ID. The full country name is used for national studies)</p> </td> 
        <td><u>Definition</u><br> (Of each Region ID)</td> 
       </tr> 
       <tr valign="top"> 
        <td><i></i></td> 
        <td colspan="3"> 
         <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
       </tr> 
       <tr valign="top"> 
        <td><i>Variable</i></td> 
        <td><u>Description</u> <br> (Of each variable for each source)</td> 
        <td><u>Varable</u> <br> (A common variable name is used for the same data item when names vary among sources)</td> 
        <td><u>Unit</u></td> 
       </tr> 
       <tr> 
        <td colspan="4"> 
         <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
       </tr> 
      </tbody>
     </table> <p><br> The database has the primary function of acting as a data storage tool, and as an interface that will allow the user easy access to the data sets contained therein. Thus, it only provides data, and analyses are conducted using other tools such as spreadsheets. However, the relational structure of the database makes it possible to call up comparable data sets across the key fields, giving maximum flexibility in manipulation, extraction, and presentation of all the data in the database. Similarly, there is great flexibility in importing new data, or making a data set from the database using combinations of specific sources, specific scenarios (or categories), specific regions, and specific variables. The extraction screen in <a href="index.php?idp=157#figV1">Figure V-1</a>, for example, shows the settings used to extract all information on all scenarios that are generated with the AIM Japan source model and to examine global sea level rise.</p> <p>The writing team recommends that this database or a new revised one should also be maintained by some institution in the future to facilitate comparisons and assessments of emissions scenarios. However, this would require additional resources.</p> </td> 
   </tr> 
  </tbody>
 </table> </td>

Mon Jun 29 14:25:45 CEST 2020: <td> <font class="simple_title">Appendix V: Database Description</font> <p>The SRES Emission Scenario Database (ESD) was developed to manage and access a large number of data sets and emissions scenarios documented in the literature. The SRES Terms of Reference call for the assessment of emissions scenarios in the literature (see <a href="index.php?idp=146">Appendix I</a>). The database was developed for SRES by the National Institute for Environmental Studies (NIES) of Japan and can be accessed via the ftp site <a href="http://www-cger.nies.go.jp/cger-e/db/ipcc.html" target="_blank">www-cger.nies.go.jp/cger-e/db/ipcc.html</a>. This section summarizes the database structure and the data collection for the database. <a href="index.php?idp=34">Chapter 2</a> gives further detail about the quantitative assessment of the scenarios in the database. At the time of writing the database included 416 scenarios from 171 sources.</p> <h2>V.1. Database Structure</h2> <p>The main purpose behind the development of the new database is to make it easier to manage and utilize the vast amounts of data related to emission scenarios of greenhouse gases (GHGs), which include carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>), nitrous oxide (N<sub>2</sub>O), methane (CH<sub>4</sub>), sulfur oxides (SO<sub>x</sub>), and related gases, (such as carbon monoxide (CO), nitrogen oxides (NO<sub>x</sub>), and hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs). The need for such a database is a function of both the increasing number of emission scenarios (because of increasing political and research interests in this topic) and the necessity to identify the strengths and weaknesses of current scenarios (to allow research to be focused on the most crucial or under-investigated areas).</p> <p>These emission scenarios have been quantified mainly using computer simulation models, which in turn utilize many assumptions on factors such as population growth, gross domestic product (GDP) growth, technology efficiency improvements, land-use changes, and the energy resource base. The assumptions used in incorporating these factors often differ between simulations, as do the actual factors represented in the simulations. As a result, the database was designed to organize and store the input assumptions behind the scenarios as well as GHG emissions and other output.</p> <p>Given the diversity of data types that must be accommodated, the database was designed with a relational database structure (using MS Access '97). The data represent large samples, and it is important that they be stored according to a structure that also allows the relationships between different data types to be represented and stored. A detailed description of the database structure is given in Morita and Lee (1998).</p> <p>Each individual data entry is stored in the DATAMOM. Using the relational structure, it is possible to call data from within any of four main fields (Source ID, Scenario ID, Region ID, or Variable) using a number of subcategories specific to the individual fields. For example, the Source ID data entry field has the following subcategories:</p> 
 <ul> 
  <li>Source ID (an abbreviated model or organization name with multiple data sets distinguished by the year of publication).</li> 
  <li>Authors (individual name or organization name).</li> 
  <li>Reference (publication in which the data are found).</li> 
  <li>Model (main simulation models).</li> 
  <li>Category (of simulation model, such as bottom-up or top-down, dynamic optimization of general equilibrium, etc.).</li> 
  <li>Update date (of the most recent publication).</li> 
  <li>Notes (if any).</li> 
 </ul> <p>Table V-1 briefly summarizes the subdivisions in the other key fields.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
 <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4"> 
  <tbody>
   <tr> 
    <td colspan="4"><i><b>Table V- 1:</b><a name="tblV1"></a> Overview of Subdivisions in Key Fields in the Scenario Database. The main data fields for the SRES ESD are shown for the field names that identify the scenario by reference and name of world region and variable type.</i></td> 
   </tr> 
   <tr> 
    <td colspan="4"> 
     <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
   </tr> 
   <tr> 
    <td><b>Field Name</b></td> 
    <td colspan="2"><b>Subdivision (and brief description)</b></td> 
    <td>&nbsp;</td> 
   </tr> 
   <tr> 
    <td colspan="4"> 
     <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
   </tr> 
   <tr valign="top"> 
    <td><i>Scenario</i></td> 
    <td><u>Scenario ID</u> <br> (For reference scenario, or specific name of scenario, if one exists)</td> 
    <td><u>Category</u> <br> (Of scenario: non- intervention, intervention, or uncertain( ty). Blank if scenario not identifiable. Non- intervention means a scenario with no reduction policies for carbon emission, but which might include policies on other GHGs)</td> 
    <td><u>Description:</u> <br> (Of scenarios storyline and main assumptions)</td> 
   </tr> 
   <tr valign="top"> 
    <td><i></i></td> 
    <td colspan="3"> 
     <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
   </tr> 
   <tr valign="top"> 
    <td><i>Region</i></td> 
    <td colspan="2"> <p><u>Region ID</u><br> (Many scenarios use different names for the same region. These are converted into one unique Region ID. The full country name is used for national studies)</p> </td> 
    <td><u>Definition</u><br> (Of each Region ID)</td> 
   </tr> 
   <tr valign="top"> 
    <td><i></i></td> 
    <td colspan="3"> 
     <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
   </tr> 
   <tr valign="top"> 
    <td><i>Variable</i></td> 
    <td><u>Description</u> <br> (Of each variable for each source)</td> 
    <td><u>Varable</u> <br> (A common variable name is used for the same data item when names vary among sources)</td> 
    <td><u>Unit</u></td> 
   </tr> 
   <tr> 
    <td colspan="4"> 
     <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
   </tr> 
  </tbody>
 </table> <p><br> The database has the primary function of acting as a data storage tool, and as an interface that will allow the user easy access to the data sets contained therein. Thus, it only provides data, and analyses are conducted using other tools such as spreadsheets. However, the relational structure of the database makes it possible to call up comparable data sets across the key fields, giving maximum flexibility in manipulation, extraction, and presentation of all the data in the database. Similarly, there is great flexibility in importing new data, or making a data set from the database using combinations of specific sources, specific scenarios (or categories), specific regions, and specific variables. The extraction screen in <a href="index.php?idp=157#figV1">Figure V-1</a>, for example, shows the settings used to extract all information on all scenarios that are generated with the AIM Japan source model and to examine global sea level rise.</p> <p>The writing team recommends that this database or a new revised one should also be maintained by some institution in the future to facilitate comparisons and assessments of emissions scenarios. However, this would require additional resources.</p> </td>
Mon Jun 29 14:25:45 CEST 2020: Invalid Data
Mon Jun 29 14:25:45 CEST 2020: Invalid Data, Trying again...
Mon Jun 29 14:25:45 CEST 2020: <td> <font class="simple_title">Appendix V: Database Description</font> <p>The SRES Emission Scenario Database (ESD) was developed to manage and access a large number of data sets and emissions scenarios documented in the literature. The SRES Terms of Reference call for the assessment of emissions scenarios in the literature (see <a href="index.php?idp=146">Appendix I</a>). The database was developed for SRES by the National Institute for Environmental Studies (NIES) of Japan and can be accessed via the ftp site <a href="http://www-cger.nies.go.jp/cger-e/db/ipcc.html" target="_blank">www-cger.nies.go.jp/cger-e/db/ipcc.html</a>. This section summarizes the database structure and the data collection for the database. <a href="index.php?idp=34">Chapter 2</a> gives further detail about the quantitative assessment of the scenarios in the database. At the time of writing the database included 416 scenarios from 171 sources.</p> <h2>V.1. Database Structure</h2> <p>The main purpose behind the development of the new database is to make it easier to manage and utilize the vast amounts of data related to emission scenarios of greenhouse gases (GHGs), which include carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>), nitrous oxide (N<sub>2</sub>O), methane (CH<sub>4</sub>), sulfur oxides (SO<sub>x</sub>), and related gases, (such as carbon monoxide (CO), nitrogen oxides (NO<sub>x</sub>), and hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs). The need for such a database is a function of both the increasing number of emission scenarios (because of increasing political and research interests in this topic) and the necessity to identify the strengths and weaknesses of current scenarios (to allow research to be focused on the most crucial or under-investigated areas).</p> <p>These emission scenarios have been quantified mainly using computer simulation models, which in turn utilize many assumptions on factors such as population growth, gross domestic product (GDP) growth, technology efficiency improvements, land-use changes, and the energy resource base. The assumptions used in incorporating these factors often differ between simulations, as do the actual factors represented in the simulations. As a result, the database was designed to organize and store the input assumptions behind the scenarios as well as GHG emissions and other output.</p> <p>Given the diversity of data types that must be accommodated, the database was designed with a relational database structure (using MS Access '97). The data represent large samples, and it is important that they be stored according to a structure that also allows the relationships between different data types to be represented and stored. A detailed description of the database structure is given in Morita and Lee (1998).</p> <p>Each individual data entry is stored in the DATAMOM. Using the relational structure, it is possible to call data from within any of four main fields (Source ID, Scenario ID, Region ID, or Variable) using a number of subcategories specific to the individual fields. For example, the Source ID data entry field has the following subcategories:</p> 
 <ul> 
  <li>Source ID (an abbreviated model or organization name with multiple data sets distinguished by the year of publication).</li> 
  <li>Authors (individual name or organization name).</li> 
  <li>Reference (publication in which the data are found).</li> 
  <li>Model (main simulation models).</li> 
  <li>Category (of simulation model, such as bottom-up or top-down, dynamic optimization of general equilibrium, etc.).</li> 
  <li>Update date (of the most recent publication).</li> 
  <li>Notes (if any).</li> 
 </ul> <p>Table V-1 briefly summarizes the subdivisions in the other key fields.<br> <br> <br> </p>

Thus, it only provides data, and analyses are conducted using other tools such as spreadsheets. However, the relational structure of the database makes it possible to call up comparable data sets across the key fields, giving maximum flexibility in manipulation, extraction, and presentation of all the data in the database. Similarly, there is great flexibility in importing new data, or making a data set from the database using combinations of specific sources, specific scenarios (or categories), specific regions, and specific variables. The extraction screen in <a href="index.php?idp=157#figV1">Figure V-1</a>, for example, shows the settings used to extract all information on all scenarios that are generated with the AIM Japan source model and to examine global sea level rise.</p> <p>The writing team recommends that this database or a new revised one should also be maintained by some institution in the future to facilitate comparisons and assessments of emissions scenarios. However, this would require additional resources.</p> </td>

           <tr> 
            <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
             <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4"> 
              <tbody>
               <tr>

     <table width="720" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0"> 
      <tbody>
       <tr> 
        <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
         <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4"> 
          <tbody>
           <tr> 
            <td colspan="4"><i><b>Table V-2:<a name="tblV2"></a></b> List of Data Categories in the 416 Scenario</i></td> 
           </tr> 
           <tr> 
            <td colspan="4"> 
             <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
           </tr> 
           <tr> 
            <td width="33%"><b>Variable</b></td>

             </div></td>

Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: Invalid Data
Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: Invalid Data, Trying again...
Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: <td align="center"> <br> 
 <table width="720" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0"> 
  <tbody>
   <tr> 
    <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
     <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4"> 
      <tbody>

 </table> </td>
Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: Invalid Data
Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: Invalid Data, Trying again...
Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
 <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4">

           <tr> 
            <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
             <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4"> 
              <tbody>
               <tr> 
                <td colspan="4"><i><b>Table V-2:<a name="tblV2"></a></b> List of Data Categories in the 416 Scenario</i></td> 
               </tr> 
               <tr> 
                <td colspan="4"> 
                 <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
               </tr> 
               <tr> 
                <td width="33%"><b>Variable</b></td>

                 </div></td> 
                <td width="34%"><b>Variable</b></td>

                 <div align="right">
                  <b>No. of Scenarios</b> 
                 </div></td> 
               </tr> 
               <tr> 
                <td colspan="2"> 
                 <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
                <td colspan="2"> 
                 <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
               </tr> 
               <tr> 
                <td width="33%" height="26">CO<sub>2</sub> emissions</td>

    <td align="center"> <br> 
     <table width="720" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0"> 
      <tbody>
       <tr> 
        <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
         <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4"> 
          <tbody>
           <tr> 
            <td colspan="4"><i><b>Table V-2:<a name="tblV2"></a></b> List of Data Categories in the 416 Scenario</i></td> 
           </tr> 
           <tr> 
            <td colspan="4"> 
             <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
           </tr> 
           <tr> 
            <td width="33%"><b>Variable</b></td>

             </div></td>

Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: Invalid Data
Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: Invalid Data, Trying again...
Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: <td align="center"> <br> 
 <table width="720" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0"> 
  <tbody>
   <tr> 
    <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
     <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4"> 
      <tbody>

     </table> <h2>References<a name="ref"></a></h2> <p><b>Alcamo</b>, J., A. Bouwman, J. Edmonds, A. Gr�bler, T. Morita, and A. Sugandhy, 1995: An Evaluation of the IPCC IS92 Emission Scenarios. In: <i>Climate Change 1994, Radiative Forcing of Climate Change and An Evaluation of the IPCC IS92 Emission Scenarios</i>, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK, pp. 233-304.</p> <p><b>Manne</b>, A., and L. Schrattenholzer, 1995:<i> International Energy Workshop January 1995 Poll Edition</i>. International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis, Laxenburg, Austria.</p> <p><b>Manne</b>, A., and L. Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: Invalid Data
Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: Invalid Data, Trying again...
Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
 <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4">

       <tr> 
        <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
         <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4">

Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: Invalid Data
Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: Invalid Data, Trying again...
Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: <td align="center"> <br> 
 <table width="720" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0"> 
  <tbody>
   <tr> 
    <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
     <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4"> 
      <tbody>
       <tr> 
        <td colspan="4"><i><b>Table V-2:<a name="tblV2"></a></b> List of Data Categories in the 416 Scenario</i></td> 
       </tr>

        <td colspan="4"> 
         <hr noshade size="1"> </td>

     </table> <h2>References<a name="ref"></a></h2> <p><b>Alcamo</b>, J., A. Bouwman, J. Edmonds, A. Gr�bler, T. Morita, and A. Sugandhy, 1995: An Evaluation of the IPCC IS92 Emission Scenarios. Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
 <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4">

 <table width="720" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0"> 
  <tbody>
   <tr> 
    <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
     <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4"> 
      <tbody>
       <tr> 
        <td colspan="4"><i><b>Table V-2:<a name="tblV2"></a></b> List of Data Categories in the 416 Scenario</i></td>

     </table> <h2>References<a name="ref"></a></h2> <p><b>Alcamo</b>, J., A. Bouwman, J. Edmonds, A. Gr�bler, T. Morita, and A. Sugandhy, 1995: An Evaluation of the IPCC IS92 Emission Scenarios. In: <i>Climate Change 1994, Radiative Forcing of Climate Change and An Evaluation of the IPCC IS92 Emission Scenarios</i>, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK, pp. 233-304.</p> <p><b>Manne</b>, A., and L. Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: Invalid Data
Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: Invalid Data, Trying again...
Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
 <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4"> 
  <tbody>

   </tr>

     <hr noshade size="1"> </td>

Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
 <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4">

          <tbody>
           <tr> 
            <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
             <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4"> 
              <tbody>
               <tr> 
                <td colspan="4"><i><b>Table V-2:<a name="tblV2"></a></b> List of Data Categories in the 416 Scenario</i></td>

             </table> <h2>References<a name="ref"></a></h2> <p><b>Alcamo</b>, J., A. Bouwman, J. Edmonds, A. Gr�bler, T. Morita, and A. Sugandhy, 1995: An Evaluation of the IPCC IS92 Emission Scenarios. In: <i>Climate Change 1994, Radiative Forcing of Climate Change and An Evaluation of the IPCC IS92 Emission Scenarios</i>, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK, pp. 233-304.</p> <p><b>Manne</b>, A., and L. Schrattenholzer, 1995:<i> International Energy Workshop January 1995 Poll Edition</i>. International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis, Laxenburg, Austria.</p> <p><b>Manne</b>, A., and L. Schrattenholzer, 1996, <i>International Energy Workshop January 1996 Poll Edition</i>. International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis, Laxenburg, Austria.</p> <p><b>Manne</b>, A., and L. Schrattenholzer, 1997: <i>International Energy Workshop, Part I: Overview of Poll Responses, Part II: Frequency Distributions, Part III: Individual Poll Responses</i>, February, 1997, International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis, Laxenburg, Austria.</p> <p><b>Morita</b>, T., and H.-C. Lee, 1998: Appendix to Emissions Scenarios Database and Review of Scenarios.<i> Mitigation and Adaptation Strategies for Global Change</i>, <b>3</b>(2-4), 121-131.</p> </td>

        <td colspan="2"> <font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="1"> <script language="JavaScript">

       <tr> 
        <td valign="top"><br><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="1"> <script language="JavaScript">
		<!--
		PrevNext(157,501);
		//-->
		</script> </font> </td> 
        <td valign="top" align="right"> <font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="1"> <a href="https://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/publications_and_data_reports.htm">Other reports in this collection</a> </font> </td>

     </table> </td> 
   </tr> 
   <tr> 
    <td align="center"> <br> 
     <table width="720" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0"> 
      <tbody>
       <tr> 
        <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
         <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4"> 
          <tbody>
           <tr> 
            <td colspan="4"><i><b>Table V-2:<a name="tblV2"></a></b> List of Data Categories in the 416 Scenario</i></td> 
           </tr>

            <td colspan="4"> 
             <hr noshade size="1"> </td> 
           </tr>

         </table> <h2>References<a name="ref"></a></h2> <p><b>Alcamo</b>, J., A. Bouwman, J. Edmonds, A. Gr�bler, T. Morita, and A. Sugandhy, 1995: An Evaluation of the IPCC IS92 Emission Scenarios. In: <i>Climate Change 1994, Radiative Forcing of Climate Change and An Evaluation of the IPCC IS92 Emission Scenarios</i>, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK, pp. 233-304.</p> <p><b>Manne</b>, A., and L. Schrattenholzer, 1997: <i>International Energy Workshop, Part I: Overview of Poll Responses, Part II: Frequency Distributions, Part III: Individual Poll Responses</i>, February, 1997, International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis, Laxenburg, Austria.</p> <p><b>Morita</b>, T., and H.-C. Lee, 1998: Appendix to Emissions Scenarios Database and Review of Scenarios.<i> Mitigation and Adaptation Strategies for Global Change</i>, <b>3</b>(2-4), 121-131.</p> </td>

Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: <td align="center"> <br>

  <tbody>
   <tr> 
    <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p>

     </table> <h2>References<a name="ref"></a></h2> <p><b>Alcamo</b>, J., A. Bouwman, J. Edmonds, A. Gr�bler, T. Morita, and A. Sugandhy, 1995: An Evaluation of the IPCC IS92 Emission Scenarios. Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: Invalid Data
Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: Invalid Data, Trying again...
Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
 <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4"> 
  <tbody>

    <td colspan="4"><i><b>Table V-2:<a name="tblV2"></a></b> List of Data Categories in the 416 Scenario</i></td> 
   </tr>

     <hr noshade size="1"> </td>

          <tbody>
           <tr> 
            <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
             <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4"> 
              <tbody>
               <tr> 
                <td colspan="4"><i><b>Table V-2:<a name="tblV2"></a></b> List of Data Categories in the 416 Scenario</i></td> 
               </tr>

                <td colspan="4"> 
                 <hr noshade size="1"> </td>

Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: Invalid Data
Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: Invalid Data, Trying again...
Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: <td>

		</script> </font> </td> 
        <td valign="top" align="right"> <font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="1"> <a href="https://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/publications_and_data_reports.htm">Other reports in this collection</a> </font> </td>

   <tr> 
    <td align="center"> <br> 
     <table width="720" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0"> 
      <tbody>
       <tr> 
        <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
         <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4"> 
          <tbody>
           <tr> 
            <td colspan="4"><i><b>Table V-2:<a name="tblV2"></a></b> List of Data Categories in the 416 Scenario</i></td> 
           </tr>

             <hr noshade size="1"> </td>

         </table> <h2>References<a name="ref"></a></h2> <p><b>Alcamo</b>, J., A. Bouwman, J. Edmonds, A. Gr�bler, T. Morita, and A. Sugandhy, 1995: An Evaluation of the IPCC IS92 Emission Scenarios.    <tr> 
    <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p>

     </table> <h2>References<a name="ref"></a></h2> <p><b>Alcamo</b>, J., A. Bouwman, J. Edmonds, A. Gr�bler, T. Morita, and A. Sugandhy, 1995: An Evaluation of the IPCC IS92 Emission Scenarios. Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: Invalid Data
Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: Invalid Data, Trying again...
Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
 <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4"> 
  <tbody>
   <tr> 
    <td colspan="4"><i><b>Table V-2:<a name="tblV2"></a></b> List of Data Categories in the 416 Scenario</i></td> 
   </tr>

     <hr noshade size="1"> </td>

       <tr> 
        <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
         <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4"> 
          <tbody>
           <tr>

Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: <td align="center"> <br> 
 <table width="720" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0"> 
  <tbody>
   <tr> 
    <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
     <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4"> 
      <tbody>

     </table> <h2>References<a name="ref"></a></h2> <p><b>Alcamo</b>, J., A. Bouwman, J. Edmonds, A. Gr�bler, T. Morita, and A. Sugandhy, 1995: An Evaluation of the IPCC IS92 Emission Scenarios. Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
 <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4">

 <table width="720" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0"> 
  <tbody>
   <tr> 
    <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
     <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4"> 
      <tbody>
       <tr>

       </tr>

     </table> <h2>References<a name="ref"></a></h2> <p><b>Alcamo</b>, J., A. Bouwman, J. Edmonds, A. Gr�bler, T. Morita, and A. Sugandhy, 1995: An Evaluation of the IPCC IS92 Emission Scenarios. Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: Invalid Data
Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: Invalid Data, Trying again...
Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p> 
 <table width="95%" align="center" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4">

Mon Jun 29 14:27:23 CEST 2020: <td> <h2>V.2. Data Collection</h2> <p>The main sources of data used in ESD were International Energy Workshop Polls (Manne and Schrattenholzer, 1995, 1996, 1997), Energy Modeling Forum (EMF-14 comparison studies) data, the previous database compiled for the IPCC Supplement Report, "Climate Change 1994" (Alcamo <i>et al</i>., 1995), which examined emission scenarios produced prior to 1994, and individual emission scenarios collected by the SRES writing team. The current database used in this report includes the results of a total of 416 scenarios from 171 sources. Most of these scenarios date after 1994.</p> <p>Most of the total of 416 scenarios focus on energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (256). Only three models estimated land-use related emissions - the ASF model, the IMAGE 2 model, and the AIM model. Very few scenarios considered global SO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p> <p>The variables considered while collating scenario data, and the frequency with which such they are found in the 416 scenarios (and thus stored in the SRES database), are listed in <a href="index.php?idp=157#tblV2">Table V-2</a>.<br> <br> <br> </p>
